title: Judgment on Tyre
shortSummary: Ezekiel 26 pronounces God's judgment against the city of Tyre for its pride and rejoicing over Jerusalem's downfall. The chapter foretells the destruction of Tyre by many nations, especially Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon, and predicts its ultimate desolation and ruin as a testimony to God's sovereignty.
timeline: c. 593 BC - During the early years of Ezekiel's prophetic ministry under Babylonian ascendancy

keyCharacters.name: Ezekiel
keyCharacters.description: The prophet receiving and delivering God's message of judgment against Tyre.

keyCharacters.name: Nebuchadrezzar
keyCharacters.description: King of Babylon, described as the instrument of God's judgment against Tyre.

keyCharacters.name: Tyre
keyCharacters.description: A wealthy and powerful Phoenician city-state, condemned for its arrogance and hostility toward Jerusalem.

outline.heading: Introduction and Indictment of Tyre
outline.description: God reveals His word to Ezekiel condemning Tyre for rejoicing over Jerusalem's destruction and promises many nations will come against Tyre, destroying its walls and towers, reducing it to a bare rock.

outline.heading: The Siege by Nebuchadrezzar
outline.description: God declares that Nebuchadrezzar, king of Babylon, will lead a powerful army to besiege Tyre, slay its people, destroy its fortifications, and plunder its wealth.

outline.heading: Complete Desolation Proclaimed
outline.description: The joyful sounds of Tyre will cease; it will be made like a bare rock, a place for fishermen’s nets, and will never be rebuilt, fulfilling God's sovereign decree.

outline.heading: The Lament of the Isles and Final Judgment
outline.description: The surrounding islands and sea princes will mourn Tyre’s fall, which will be so complete that it will be forgotten and become a terror, never to be inhabited again.

application: Trust in God's sovereignty: Recognize that God controls the rise and fall of nations and individuals, and His judgments are just.
Avoid pride and rejoicing over others' misfortunes: Tyre's arrogance and gloating over Jerusalem's destruction brought God's judgment; humility is essential.
Pray for cities and nations: Intercede for those who oppose God's people, trusting God to work His purposes even through judgment.
Remember the consequences of opposing God: Obedience to God brings blessing, while rebellion leads to destruction and desolation.

keyVerses.text: And they shall destroy the walls of Tyrus, and break down her towers: I will also scrape her dust from her, and make her like the top of a rock.
keyVerses.significance: This verse vividly depicts the total destruction God will bring upon Tyre, emphasizing His power over seemingly impregnable cities.

keyVerses.text: For thus saith the Lord GOD; Behold, I will bring upon Tyrus Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon, a king of kings, from the north, with horses, and with chariots, and with horsemen, and companies, and much people.
keyVerses.significance: Identifies Nebuchadrezzar as God's chosen instrument of judgment, showing God's sovereignty over earthly rulers.

keyVerses.text: And I will make thee like the top of a rock: thou shalt be a place to spread nets upon; thou shalt be built no more: for I the LORD have spoken it, saith the Lord GOD.
keyVerses.significance: Confirms the irrevocable nature of God's judgment and the permanent desolation of Tyre.

keyVerses.text: I will make thee a terror, and thou shalt be no more: though thou be sought for, yet shalt thou never be found again, saith the Lord GOD.
keyVerses.significance: Highlights the complete and final destruction of Tyre, serving as a warning about opposing God's will.
